results.title: Reach for the stars (Captioned)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Teenagers’ guide to the galaxy”.
Part of a series developed for young people aged 9-16 which deals with issues of communication skills, interpersonal skills, life skills and problem solving. “Reach for the stars” is all about your potential, your future and what you will be doing for the rest of your life. It discusses how you can help achieve that path to success or make your dreams come true and includes hints and worldly advice from teenagers and adults about decision-making; career choices; motivation; setting goals; initiative; self belief and potential. Features Colette Mann as Fay.

results.title: Reach for the sky [study extract]
results.creator_credit: Lewis Gilbert, Daniel M. Angel and BFI
results.brief_description: This extract is from an early part of the biographical film on Douglas Bader. Bader’s crash (a result of showing off after being needled by civilians) resulted in the amputation of both his legs in December 1931. He has had a “peg leg” and crutches, but now he has met Thelma, who is working as a waitress and is determined to dance with her. The extract is concerned with the situations arising from Bader’s loss of legs and with his growing friendship with Thelma, who later becomes his wife. Cast includes Kenneth More, Muriel Pavlow, Sidney Tafler and Jack Walting.

results.title: Rays from atoms
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Atomic physics: an historical approach”.
A five part series designed for use in the science departments of universities, technical colleges, and schools teaching advanced physics, tracing the development of atomic energy from the days when John Dalton put forward his atomic theory in 1808, until the present day. This episode (part 2) deals with the development of X-rays and cathode rays.

results.title: Rayon: first among fibres
results.creator_credit: Lawrence Crabb, Raymond Spottiswoode, Courtaulds and Film Centre (International)
results.brief_description: The discovery of viscose rayon and the complex chemical processes of production. Laboratory and factory sequences show the development of rayon from normal textile yarns to high tenacity yarns and polynosic fibres.

results.title: Raymond Loewy: father of industrial design
results.creator_credit: Suzanne St Pierre, 60 Minutes and CBS News
results.brief_description: Raymond Loewy’s streamlined functionalism has set the standards in modern industrial design for 70 years. Loewy animatedly discusses the elements of good design, and strolls through a hardware store finding ineffectively designed items among the store’s wares. At 85 he is as sharp as ever, and still working to improve the most ordinary object. Includes his personal philosophy on the function of the designer.

results.title: Raygun's nightmare
results.creator_credit: Peter Wallach, David Jablin, Atlantic Television and Imagination Productions
results.brief_description: An animated satire combining a mixture of live, puppets and computer animation, on American politics in which President Raygun has a terrible nightmare about the invasion of America by a huge Japanese electronic monster. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Ray Powell
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Dance: Videos of Australian dancers and choreographers”.
Ray Powell entered the “Sadler’s Wells Ballet Scool” in 1940 and trained with Nikolai Sergeyev. He joined the “Sadler’s Wells Ballet Company” and speaks with admiration of the leadership of Ninette de Valois and the example of professionalism set by Sir Robert Helpmann and Dame Margot Fonteyn despite the difficulties of performing in wartime London. In 1962 Peggy van Praagh invited Powell to join the “Australian Ballet” as a dancer and ballet master. He talks about the early days of the company and his memory of guest artists, including Rudolf Nureyev, Dame Alicia Markova and Anthony Tudor. In 1982, Powell became a teacher at the “Australian Ballet School” where he shares a lifetime of experience with a new generation of Australian dancers. Researched and interviewed by James Murdoch.

results.title: Raving waving
results.creator_credit: Stuart Wynn Jones and Grasshopper Group
results.brief_description: An experiment in animation technique produced by a group of amateur filmmakers. Abstract wave movements are animated in time with rhythmic “musique concrete”, the sound track of which was edited note by note on tape.

results.title: Rats of Tobruk
results.brief_description: The upcoming film from Phillip Noyce is ‘a story of how a diverse bunch of Aussie blokes – including a farmer, a schoolteacher, an Indigenous Australian boxing champ and a former safe breaker - helped turn the course of history – setting their courage, camaraderie and ingenuity against the German “blitzkrieg”.

constellations_other.name: Australia and WW2
constellations_other.description: A constellation exploring representations of Australians during World War 2.

results.description: The upcoming film from director Phillip Noyce is ‘a story of how a diverse bunch of Aussie blokes – including a farmer, a schoolteacher, an Indigenous Australian boxing champ and a former safe breaker - helped turn the course of history – setting their courage, camaraderie and ingenuity against the German “blitzkrieg”, comprising dive-bombers, Panzer tanks and battle-hardened infantry.’ The film is based on Noyce’s father’s wartime diaries.
description_for_label: The upcoming film from director Phillip Noyce is ‘a story of how a diverse bunch of Aussie blokes – including a farmer, a schoolteacher, an Indigenous Australian boxing champ and a former safe breaker - helped turn the course of history – setting their courage, camaraderie and ingenuity against the German “blitzkrieg”, comprising dive-bombers, Panzer tanks and battle-hardened infantry.’ The film is based on Noyce’s father’s wartime diaries.

results.title: Rational suicide
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “60 Minutes”.
To some perfectly rational people afflicted with pain and incurable disease, rational suicide has become a real and plausible option. Others believe that you don’t have to kill the patient to kill the pain. The film examines both sides of the argument, including an interview with a man who assisted his terminally ill wife in taking her own life.
